articles.headline: Under Trump, an Office Meant to Help Refugees Enters the Abortion Wars
articles.snippet: One small government office has become the flash point in the debate over the administration’s embrace of socially conservative policy.
articles.abstract: One small government office has become the flash point in the debate over the administration’s embrace of socially conservative policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Scott Lloyd’s unadorned job title betrays little hint of the power he has over the pregnant teenagers in his custody.

articles.headline: Consumer Bureau’s Chief Gives Big Raises, Even as He Criticizes Spending
articles.snippet: Mick Mulvaney, who is trying to rein in the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, awarded large pay increases to two recent recruits.
articles.abstract: Mick Mulvaney, who is trying to rein in the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, awarded large pay increases to two recent recruits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mick Mulvaney, the acting director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, has complained that the regulator engages in “wasteful spending” and needs to be slimmed down. To underscore the point, he submitted a quarterly budget request recently that was a nice round number: $0.

articles.headline: E.P.A. Officials Sidelined After Questioning Scott Pruitt
articles.snippet: At least five agency officials were reassigned or demoted, or requested new jobs after raising concerns about the administrator’s security demands and spending.
articles.abstract: At least five agency officials were reassigned or demoted, or requested new jobs after raising concerns about the administrator’s security demands and spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At least five officials at the Environmental Protection Agency, four of them high-ranking, were reassigned or demoted, or requested new jobs in the past year after they raised concerns about the spending and management of the agency’s administrator, Scott Pruitt.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Kenneth P. Vogel and Lisa Friedman

articles.headline: Trump Doubles Down on Potential Trade War With China
articles.snippet: President Trump said he would consider tariffs on $100 billion more in Chinese goods in retaliation for Beijing’s plan to set levies on American products.
articles.abstract: President Trump said he would consider tariffs on $100 billion more in Chinese goods in retaliation for Beijing’s plan to set levies on American products.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said Thursday that the United States would consider slapping tariffs on an additional $100 billion in Chinese goods, escalating a potentially damaging trade dispute with Beijing.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Too Radical for France, a Muslim Clergyman Faces Deportation
articles.snippet: President Emmanuel Macron, who has taken advantage of his office’s powers, appears poised to expel El Hadi Doudi, making clear he won’t tolerate radical preachers.
articles.abstract: President Emmanuel Macron, who has taken advantage of his office’s powers, appears poised to expel El Hadi Doudi, making clear he won’t tolerate radical preachers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARSEILLE, France — No ordinary preacher, El Hadi Doudi is perhaps France’s leading proponent of fundamentalist Islam. His influence extends throughout Europe, where his lawyer says the cleric is the only imam authorized to issue fatwas. Over 37 years, he has often berated Jews, women and the modern world, yet the authorities have tolerated his hard-line sermons and occasionally cultivated him as an ally.

articles.headline: Bright Lights, Big Shoulder Pads: A Timid Japan Recalls Its Bubble Era
articles.snippet: The country’s mild new prosperity has rekindled an interest in the 1980s, when the Japanese economy truly boomed and a sense of ascendance fueled spenders.
articles.abstract: The country’s mild new prosperity has rekindled an interest in the 1980s, when the Japanese economy truly boomed and a sense of ascendance fueled spenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Kaori Masukodera remembers, barely, riding as a child with her mother, her hair teased and her lips bright red, in the family’s convertible to the beach. It was the last gasp of the 1980s, a time of Champagne, garish colors and bubbly disco dance-floor anthems, and the last time many people in Japan felt rich and ascendant.

articles.headline: Pompeo and Bolton Appointments Raise Alarm Over Ties to Anti-Islam Groups
articles.snippet: Mike Pompeo is President Trump’s pick to be the next secretary of state, and John R. Bolton is the choice for national security adviser. Civil rights groups are concerned.
articles.abstract: Mike Pompeo is President Trump’s pick to be the next secretary of state, and John R. Bolton is the choice for national security adviser. Civil rights groups are concerned.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly two months after the Boston Marathon bombing, Mike Pompeo, then a congressman from Kansas, took to the floor of the House to denounce American Muslim leaders for what he called their “silence” in response to the heinous terrorist attack.

articles.headline: U.S. and China Play Chicken on Trade, and Neither Swerves
articles.snippet: Victory could be difficult to verify, much less achieve, as the U.S. protests Beijing’s effort to retool Chinese industries for the 21st century.
articles.abstract: Victory could be difficult to verify, much less achieve, as the U.S. protests Beijing’s effort to retool Chinese industries for the 21st century.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — At the heart of the intensifying trade dispute between the United States and China is a fundamental question: Which country is more willing to endure short-term pain for the long-term gain of playing a leading role in high-tech industries.
